Views

  1. Introduction
  2. Defining views
  3. How to use them
  4. View parameters
  5. Special implicit values
  6. View filters
  7. Bindings

Introduction

Views are part of the rendering system, which is based on the Opis View library, and they are used to display user defined content. Views are collected using the Views method. 

use Opis\Colibri\Define;

Define::Views(function($view){

    // Collect views

});

The collector passed to the callback function is an object that implements the Opis\Colibri\ViewCollectorInterface interface. 

interface ViewCollectorInterface
{
    /**
     * Defines a new view route
     *
     * @param   string      $pattern    View's pattern
     * @param   callable    $resolver   A callback that will resolve the view's path
     * @param   int         $priority   Route's priority
     *
     * @return  \Opis\View\Route
     */
    
    public function handle($pattern, $resolver, $priority = 0);
}

Defining views

Views are defined by passing a view name and a callback value to the handle method. The view's callback value must return the path where the view's content is located. 

use Opis\Colibri\Define;

Define::Views(function($view){

    $view->handle('foo', function(){
        return __DIR__ . '/views/foo.php';
    });

});

You can override an existing view by passing a third parameter to the handle method. This parameter must be an integer number and represents the view's collecting priority. The default collecting priority of a view is 0. 

use Opis\Colibri\Define;

Define::Views(function($view){

    $view->handle('foo', function(){
        return __DIR__ . '/views/bar.php';
    }, 1);

});

A view's name can also be divided into segments separated by . signs. 

use Opis\Colibri\Define;

Define::Views(function($view){

    $view->handle('foo.bar', function(){
        return __DIR__ . '/views/foobar.php';
    });

});

How to use them

A view must be used in conjunction with an object that implements the Opis\View\ViewableInterface interface. The easiest way of creating such an object is by using the View global function.

Let's assume we have defined a view named foo, we have associated a file with that view, and we have also created some routes that utilize our foo view. 

<!-- /views/foo.php -->
<h1>
    <?php print $title; ?>
</h1>

use Opis\Colibri\Define;

Define::Routes(function($route){

    $route('/some/path', function(){
        return View('foo', ['title' => 'Hello world!']);
    });
    
    $route('/other/path', function(){
        return View('foo', ['title' => 'Views are great!']);
    });

});

Define::Views(function($view){

    $view->handle('foo', function(){
        return __DIR__ . '/views/foo.php';
    });

});

As you can see, not only that you can use the same view in different places, but you can also specify different values for a view's variables.

But what if you want to change how a specific view is rendered? What if you want to replace, in the above example, the h1 tag with the h2 tag? Of course, you can just modify the content of the view's associated file and you are done, but that's not a viable option, especially if the view was defined by another module. By doing so, if the module was distributed by a third party, you will be forced to modify the file every time the module gets an update, and that can quickly become overwhelming when you have to modify multiple files. The solution to this problem is very simple: override the view and associate it with another file. 

<!-- /views/bar.php -->
<h2>
    <?php print $title; ?>
</h2>

use Opis\Colibri\Define;

Define::Views(function($view){

    $view->handle('foo', function(){
        return __DIR__ . '/views/bar.php';
    }, 1);

});

That's it, that's all you have to do!

View parameters

You can transform view names or a view segments into parameters by enclosing them with curly braces. The parameters can be then used by the callback, by simply adding them into the callback's arguments list. 

use Opis\Colibri\Define;

Define::Views(function($view){

    $view->handle('{foo}', function($foo){
        return __DIR__ . '/views/' . $foo . '.php';
    });
    
    $view->handle('foo.{bar}', function($bar){
        return __DIR__ . '/views/foo/' . $bar . '.php';
    });

});

You can define as many parameters as you need. 

use Opis\Colibri\Define;

Define::Views(function($view){

    
    $view->handle('foo.{bar}.baz.{qux}', function($bar, $qux){
        //
    });

});
Optional parameters

Specifying that a parameter is optional can be done by adding a ? mark after the parameter name. 

use Opis\Colibri\Define;

Define::Views(function($view){

    $view->handle('foo.{bar?}', function($bar = 'baz'){
        return __DIR__ . '/views/foo/' . $bar . '.php';
    });

});
Implicit values

You can add an implicit value for a parameter name using the implicit method. 

use Opis\Colibri\Define;

Define::Views(function($view){

    $view->handle('foo.{bar?}', function($bar){
        return __DIR__ . '/views/foo/' . $bar . '.php';
    })
    ->implicit('bar', 'baz');

});
Regex constraints

You can add regex constraints to parameters by using the where method. The method takes as arguments the parameter name and a regular expression defining how the parameter should be constrained. 

use Opis\Colibri\Define;

Define::Views(function($view){

    $view->handle('foo.{bar?}', function($bar){
        return __DIR__ . '/views/foo/' . $bar . '.php';
    })
    ->implicit('bar', 'baz')
    ->where('bar', '[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z0-9_-]+');

});

Special implicit values

There are two special implicit values: self and path. The self implicit's value is the current route instance and path implicit's value is the current path object, which is an instance of the Opis\Routing\Path class. 

use Opis\Colibri\Define;

Define::Views(function($view){

    $view->handle('foo', function($self, $path){
        //
    });

});

View filters

You can add a filter to a view by passing a callback value to the filter method. The callback must return either true or false. The filter is executed before binding takes place. 

use Opis\Colibri\Define;

Define::Views(function($view){

    $view->handle('foo.{bar}', function($bar){
        return __DIR__ . '/views/foo/' . $bar . '.php';
    })
    ->filter(function($bar){
        return file_exists(__DIR__ . '/views/foo/' . $bar . '.php');
    });

});

Bindings

Binding an identifier to a value can be done by using the bind method. 

use Opis\Colibri\Define;

Define::Views(function($view){

    $view->handle('foo.{bar}', function($file){
        return $file;
    })
    ->filter(function($bar){
        return file_exists(__DIR__ . '/views/foo/' . $bar . '.php');
    })
    ->bind('file', function($bar){
        return __DIR__ . '/views/foo/' . $bar . '.php';
    });

});
